Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Situation2: A heated dispute has escalated to the point where they are questioning staying together.
Story: I sat at the dinner table, nodding along as my parents and brother tossed around ideas for our weekend together—maybe a hike, or a movie night. My mom looked at me, her eyes hopeful, “You’ll be there, right? We haven’t all spent time together in ages.” I smiled, but my phone buzzed in my lap. It was a long message from Alex, my boyfriend. The argument we’d had earlier was still raw, and now he was saying he didn’t know if we could keep going unless we talked things through tonight. My heart pounded. My family expected me to be present, to laugh and plan and show I cared. But Alex needed me to be his partner, to help fix what was breaking between us. I felt split in two, guilt pressing on both sides. I wanted to be the sister who showed up, but I also wanted to be the girlfriend who didn’t give up. My family’s voices faded as I stared at my phone, torn between the two worlds that both needed me right now.
